solution:
You can use 8 as the common denominator.
Multiply the numerator and the denominator of $\frac{1}{2}$ by 4 to find an equivalent fraction.
$\frac{1 \times 4}{2 \times 4} = \frac{4}{8}$

Now add the fractions. Add the numerators and keep the denominators the same.
$\frac{1}{8} + \frac{4}{8} = \frac{5}{8}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 3 and 10.\nLCD = 30
Convert each fraction to an equivalent fraction with denominator 30:\n$\\frac{1}{3} = \\frac{10}{30}$ and $\\frac{9}{10} = \\frac{27}{30}$
Add the numerators and keep the common denominator:\n$\\frac{10}{30} + \\frac{27}{30} = \\frac{37}{30}$
Simplify if possible:\n$\\frac{37}{30} = \\frac{37}{30}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 4 and 3.\nLCD = 12
Convert each fraction to an equivalent fraction with denominator 12:\n$\\frac{3}{4} = \\frac{9}{12}$ and $\\frac{2}{3} = \\frac{8}{12}$
Add the numerators and keep the common denominator:\n$\\frac{9}{12} + \\frac{8}{12} = \\frac{17}{12}$
Simplify if possible:\n$\\frac{17}{12} = \\frac{17}{12}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 5 and 8.\nLCD = 40
Convert each fraction to an equivalent fraction with denominator 40:\n$\\frac{1}{5} = \\frac{8}{40}$ and $\\frac{5}{8} = \\frac{25}{40}$
Add the numerators and keep the common denominator:\n$\\frac{8}{40} + \\frac{25}{40} = \\frac{33}{40}$
Simplify if possible:\n$\\frac{33}{40} = \\frac{33}{40}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 8 and 6.\nLCD = 24
Convert each fraction to an equivalent fraction with denominator 24:\n$\\frac{7}{8} = \\frac{21}{24}$ and $\\frac{2}{6} = \\frac{8}{24}$
Add the numerators and keep the common denominator:\n$\\frac{21}{24} + \\frac{8}{24} = \\frac{29}{24}$
Simplify if possible:\n$\\frac{29}{24} = \\frac{29}{24}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 12 and 4.\nLCD = 12
Convert each fraction to an equivalent fraction with denominator 12:\n$\\frac{5}{12} = \\frac{5}{12}$ and $\\frac{3}{4} = \\frac{9}{12}$
Add the numerators and keep the common denominator:\n$\\frac{5}{12} + \\frac{9}{12} = \\frac{14}{12}$
Simplify if possible:\n$\\frac{14}{12} = \\frac{7}{6}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 5 and 10.\nLCD = 10
Convert each fraction to an equivalent fraction with denominator 10:\n$\\frac{4}{5} = \\frac{8}{10}$ and $\\frac{9}{10} = \\frac{9}{10}$
Add the numerators and keep the common denominator:\n$\\frac{8}{10} + \\frac{9}{10} = \\frac{17}{10}$
Simplify if possible:\n$\\frac{17}{10} = \\frac{17}{10}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 10 and 2.\nLCD = 10
Convert each fraction to an equivalent fraction with denominator 10:\n$\\frac{2}{10} = \\frac{2}{10}$ and $\\frac{1}{2} = \\frac{5}{10}$
Add the numerators and keep the common denominator:\n$\\frac{2}{10} + \\frac{5}{10} = \\frac{7}{10}$
Simplify if possible:\n$\\frac{7}{10} = \\frac{7}{10}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 3 and 10.\nLCD = 30
Convert each fraction to an equivalent fraction with denominator 30:\n$\\frac{2}{3} = \\frac{20}{30}$ and $\\frac{5}{10} = \\frac{15}{30}$
Add the numerators and keep the common denominator:\n$\\frac{20}{30} + \\frac{15}{30} = \\frac{35}{30}$
Simplify if possible:\n$\\frac{35}{30} = \\frac{7}{6}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 2 and 10.\nLCD = 10
Convert each fraction to an equivalent fraction with denominator 10:\n$\\frac{1}{2} = \\frac{5}{10}$ and $\\frac{4}{10} = \\frac{4}{10}$
Add the numerators and keep the common denominator:\n$\\frac{5}{10} + \\frac{4}{10} = \\frac{9}{10}$
Simplify if possible:\n$\\frac{9}{10} = \\frac{9}{10}$

Add the numerators and keep the common denominator:\n$\\frac{2}{10} + \\frac{5}{10} = \\frac{7}{10}$
Simplify if possible:\n$\\frac{7}{10} = \\frac{7}{10}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 8 and 6.\nLCD = 24
Convert each fraction to an equivalent fraction with denominator 24:\n$\\frac{2}{8} = \\frac{6}{24}$ and $\\frac{2}{6} = \\frac{8}{24}$
Add the numerators and keep the common denominator:\n$\\frac{6}{24} + \\frac{8}{24} = \\frac{14}{24}$
Simplify if possible:\n$\\frac{14}{24} = \\frac{7}{12}$
Find the least common denominator (LCD) of 12 and 10.\nLCD = 60
Convert each fraction to an equivalent fraction with denominator 60:\n$\\frac{8}{12} = \\frac{40}{60}$ and $\\frac{3}{10} = \\frac{18}{60}$
Add the numerators and keep the common denominator:\n$\\frac{40}{60} + \\frac{18}{60} = \\frac{58}{60}$

Add the numerators and keep the common denominator:\n$\\frac{5}{12} + \\frac{4}{12} = \\frac{9}{12}$
Simplify if possible:\n$\\frac{9}{12} = \\frac{3}{4}$

Add the numerators and keep the common denominator:\n$\\frac{15}{20} + \\frac{16}{20} = \\frac{31}{20}$

Add the numerators and keep the common denominator:\n$\\frac{6}{12} + \\frac{4}{12} = \\frac{10}{12}$

Add the numerators and keep the common denominator:\n$\\frac{8}{10} + \\frac{9}{10} = \\frac{17}{10}$

Add the numerators and keep the common denominator:\n$\\frac{2}{4} + \\frac{2}{4} = \\frac{4}{4}$
Simplify if possible:\n$\\frac{4}{4} = \\frac{1}{1}$

Convert each fraction to an equivalent fraction with denominator 8:\n$\\frac{1}{2} = \\frac{4}{8}$ and $\\frac{4}{8} = \\frac{4}{8}$
